description.overview: A perennial, aromatic, rhizomatous herb essential to Southeast Asian and Indian cuisine, with a centuries-old role in traditional medicine for diverse ailments.
description.habitat: Native to tropical Southeast Asia; widely cultivated throughout India, Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia, and southern China in forests, fields, and garden plots.

iucn_status.status: Not Evaluated (NE) globally; not listed as threatened. Some related Zingiberaceae are regionally endangered due to habitat loss.

traditional_uses.context: Decoctions from the rhizome used for indigestion, bloating, and loss of appetite in Ayurveda and traditional Thai, Malay, and Javanese medicine.
Powdered rhizome or teas for cough, sore throat, bronchitis, and mouth/larynx freshness.
Crushed rhizome or infusions rubbed onto the body for muscle aches, neuralgia, joint pain, and general warming (balms used in Thai massage).
Used for erectile dysfunction and as an emmenagogue in Unani and Siddha traditions.
Ingested after suspected food poisoning, worms, or other 'contaminations.'
Treats constipation, urinary issues, and mild dental complaints; also used in rituals.

major_constituents: Essential oils (1′-acetoxychavicol acetate, 1,8-cineole, eugenol, methyl cinnamate, camphor)

pharmacological_activities.name: Anti-inflammatory
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Inhibits production of TNF-α, COX-2, and boosts IL-10, TGF-β; due to diarylheptanoids and flavonoids.
pharmacological_activities.evidence: Multiple animal model studies and in vitro work confirm acute and chronic anti-inflammation (Darvish et al., Phytother Res. 2016; Khan et al., J. Pharm. Pharmacol. 2019)[1][2].

pharmacological_activities.name: Antimicrobial
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Essential oil and rhizome extracts inhibit Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria and fungal pathogens; diterpenoids are implicated.
pharmacological_activities.evidence: Strong in vitro and some in vivo evidence for antibacterial and antifungal effects (Song et al., Molecules 2017)[3].

pharmacological_activities.name: Antioxidant
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Scavenging of radicals (DPPH, ABTS) through phenolic content.
pharmacological_activities.evidence: Chompoo et al., Food Chem. 2014; in vitro/animal models[4].

pharmacological_activities.name: Gastroprotective
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Prevents ethanol-induced ulcers in rat models, likely via mucosal protection.

pharmacological_activities.name: COX-2 inhibition
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Direct suppression of cyclooxygenase-2 enzyme (inflammation).

pharmacological_activities.name: Antidiabetic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Inhibits α-glucosidase, helping lower post-meal blood sugar spikes.
pharmacological_activities.evidence: Bhandari et al., J. Diabetes Res. 2018[7].

pharmacological_activities.name: Cytotoxic / anticancer
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Extracts active against HepG2 liver cells, MCF-7 breast cancer lines (inducing apoptosis).

pharmacological_activities.name: Larvicidal
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Kills mosquito larvae (Aedes aegypti).

pharmacological_activities.name: Anti-arthritic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Reduces swelling and immune infiltration in arthritis animal models.
pharmacological_activities.evidence: Khan et al., J. Pharm. Pharmacol. 2019[2].

pharmacological_activities.name: Neuroprotective
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Improves alertness/mood (synergy with caffeine); possible protection against neurodegeneration.
pharmacological_activities.evidence: Human clinical trials (Wesnes et al., Appetite 2017)[10].

modern_applications: Standardized rhizome extracts in herbal teas, digestive formulas, immune support, and anti-inflammatory supplements.
Active ingredient in topical creams, gels, and Thai balms for pain/inflammation.
Bioactive flavoring and essential oil in food and beverage industries.
Ingredient in oral care (mouthwashes, toothpaste); minor cosmetic uses.

safety.acute_toxicity: No acute toxicity up to 2,000 mg/kg in rodent studies; LD50 above 2,000 mg/kg (ethanolic extract).
safety.chronic_toxicity: Long-term high-dose administration can cause mild liver and kidney changes in animals; considered low-risk in human food/medicinal doses.
precautions: Not for unsupervised use in pregnancy or breastfeeding.
Use with care in gallstone patients and those with sensitive GI tracts.
Monitor for drug-herb interactions if used with prescription medications.
Avoid unprocessed rhizome in those with spice allergies.
sources: WHO Monographs on Selected Medicinal Plants (Vol. 4)

references: Khan et al., J. Pharm. Pharmacol. 2019
Bhandari et al., J. Diabetes Res. 2018
WHO Monographs; CO’s Digital Flora of the Philippines

description.overview: A fast-growing annual herbaceous plant valued for its edible leaves and seeds, used both as a vegetable and for its medicinal properties in various traditional systems.
description.habitat: Widely distributed in tropical and subtropical regions of Asia, Africa, and the Americas; common in disturbed soils, waste places, and cultivated as a leafy vegetable.

sources: IUCN Red List (2024): Not assessed for this species.

traditional_uses.context: Leaf decoction traditionally administered to reduce fever and relieve headache in Ayurveda and African herbal medicine.
Leaves consumed post-partum to promote lactation in Indian and Southeast Asian folk medicine.
Widely cooked as a nutritious ‘saag’ or green in Indian, African, and Southeast Asian cuisines.
Seeds and leaves used in mild constipation and some folk diarrheal remedies.

major_constituents: Phenolic acids (e.g. gallic acid, ferulic acid)

pharmacological_activities.name: Antioxidant
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Scavenges free radicals and reduces erythrocyte oxidative stress via polyphenolic compounds.

pharmacological_activities.name: Hepatoprotective
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Protects against chemically-induced liver damage in animal models.

pharmacological_activities.name: Analgesic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Reduces pain responses in hot-plate and writhing models.
pharmacological_activities.evidence: Murthy et al., Asian Pac J Trop Biomed. 2017

pharmacological_activities.name: Anti-diarrheal
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Modulates intestinal motility; reduces gut inflammation.

pharmacological_activities.name: Antimicrobial
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Inhibits growth of pathogenic bacteria and some fungi.
pharmacological_activities.evidence: Radhakrishnan & Sapna, BMC Complement Altern Med. 2016

pharmacological_activities.name: Anti-inflammatory
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Suppresses expression of pro-inflammatory cytokines, especially TNF-alpha.

modern_applications: Used as a functional leafy green in nutrition-sensitive programs.
Leaf extracts studied for antioxidant supplements.
Potential source of natural colorants (betalains) and dietary fiber in foods.

safety.acute_toxicity: Demonstrates low toxicity; safe up to 500 µg/mL in cell-line studies and in traditional dietary intake.
safety.chronic_toxicity: No significant safety issues reported in humans at dietary levels.
precautions: High or prolonged usage may cause mild digestive upset.
Consult healthcare provider for medicinal use during pregnancy.
sources: Patel et al., J. Toxicol Sci. 2018

references: Murthy et al., Asian Pac J Trop Biomed. 2017
Radhakrishnan & Sapna, BMC Complement Altern Med. 2016

description.overview: A large evergreen tropical tree with the largest tree-borne fruit, valued for its food and medicinal uses in South Asia.
description.habitat: Native to the Western Ghats of India; cultivated throughout tropical Asia, Africa, and the Americas. Thrives in humid tropical forests and plantations.

sources: IUCN Red List (2024), India Biodiversity Portal

traditional_uses.context: Applied to wounds, ulcers, and skin infections for antiseptic effect.
Decoction from fruit pulp or latex to alleviate cough and sore throat.
Leaf infusions given in traditional medicine for respiratory symptoms and asthma.
Consumed as ripe or unripe fruit (curries & desserts); seeds also eaten as protein source.

pharmacological_activities.name: Anthelmintic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Destroys intestinal helminths in rodent models.

pharmacological_activities.name: Anti-diabetic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Improves insulin sensitivity and reduces blood glucose.

pharmacological_activities.name: Antioxidant
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Scavenges free radicals and enhances antioxidant capacity (FRAP assay).
pharmacological_activities.evidence: Han et al., Food Sci Nutr. 2017

pharmacological_activities.name: Hepatoprotective
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Reduces chemically-induced liver injury.

pharmacological_activities.name: Anti-inflammatory
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Suppression of inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β).

pharmacological_activities.name: Cytotoxic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Anti-proliferative against cancer cell lines (MCF-7, HeLa).

pharmacological_activities.name: Wound healing
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Increases tissue repair and healing in models of excision wounds.

pharmacological_activities.name: Antimicrobial
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Active against a range of bacteria, including E. coli and Candida albicans.

modern_applications: Fruit powders and extracts in health foods and snack bars.
Jackfruit latex/plant extract in wound-healing and skincare products.
Potential dietary fiber supplement and ingredient for meat alternatives.

safety.acute_toxicity: LD50 > 5 g/kg in mice (fruit extract); considered safe as food and folk remedy.
safety.chronic_toxicity: No safety issues noted from consumption of ripe fruit.
precautions: Allergic reactions possible in latex-sensitive individuals.
Unripe latex (high concentration) for internal use is not advised.
sources: Ghosh et al., Toxicol Ind Health 2017
Regulatory & risk assessment reports (Food Safety Authority of India)

references: Han et al., Food Sci Nutr. 2017

description.overview: An evergreen tree, highly esteemed in Indian traditional medicine, agriculture, and personal care for its powerful bioactive compounds.
description.habitat: Native to Indian subcontinent; planted and naturalized throughout tropical Asia and Africa. Drought tolerant; grows well in arid/semi-arid zones.

iucn_status.status: Not Evaluated (NE) globally; widely available and not considered threatened.
sources: WHO Monographs; no IUCN Red List entry

traditional_uses.context: Leaves and bark administered alongside antivenom for snake bites (Ayurveda).
Leaves (Nimba churna) used in blood purification and as part of 'panchakarma' for detox in Ayurveda.
Crushed leaves and oil applied to boils, eczema, and wounds as antiseptic.
Neem twigs chewed as herbal toothbrush; leaf/stem extracts for mouthwashes.
Seeds and oil applied as traditional biopesticide and anti-fungal agent.

pharmacological_activities.name: Antimicrobial
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Broad-spectrum inhibition of bacteria, fungi, protozoa.

pharmacological_activities.name: Antimalarial
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Inhibits Plasmodium falciparum.

pharmacological_activities.name: Insecticidal
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Active compounds (azadirachtin) disrupt pest hormonal systems.

pharmacological_activities.name: Anti-hyperglycemic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Protects pancreatic β-cells, lowers glucose.

pharmacological_activities.name: Anti-inflammatory
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Suppression of inflammatory pathways (COX, cytokines).

pharmacological_activities.name: Hepatoprotective
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Protects liver against toxins.

pharmacological_activities.name: Cardioprotective
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Reduces myocardial injury in animal models.
pharmacological_activities.evidence: Singh et al., J. Appl. Pharm Sci. 2018

pharmacological_activities.name: Dental plaque inhibition
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Inhibits biofilm formation by oral bacteria.
pharmacological_activities.evidence: Prabhakar et al., Arch Oral Biol. 2016

pharmacological_activities.name: Immunomodulatory
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Enhances immune response in animal and in vitro models.

pharmacological_activities.name: Skin lightening
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Tyrosinase inhibition; reduces pigmentation.
pharmacological_activities.evidence: Lee et al., J Cosmet Sci. 2018

modern_applications: Neem oil and extracts in eco-friendly agriculture (biopesticides).
Ingredients in oral hygiene, dermatology and cosmetic products.
Leaf extract used in supplements for immune and glucose support.

safety.acute_toxicity: Oral leaf/bark use up to 1g/day tolerated in adults. Oils more toxic; minimum lethal dose in children approx 5 ml undiluted oil.
safety.chronic_toxicity: Long-term use may cause hepatic stress at high doses.
precautions: Avoid large doses of seed oil internally, especially in young children.
Not recommended in pregnancy or for infants.
Possible allergies (oral or contact) in sensitive individuals.
sources: WHO Monograph on Selected Medicinal Plants (2013)

references: Singh et al., J. Appl. Pharm Sci. 2018
Prabhakar et al., Arch Oral Biol. 2016
Lee et al., J Cosmet Sci. 2018

description.overview: A small perennial under-shrub, crucial in Ayurveda’s Dashamoola, valued for anti-inflammatory and rejuvenating action.
description.habitat: Naturally found throughout India, Southeast Asia, and the Himalayas; prefers open grasslands, forest margins and dry-waste lands.

iucn_status.status: Least Concern (LC), but locally scarce due to over-collection for Ayurveda.
sources: Plants of the World Online (Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew)

traditional_uses.context: Decoction/pastes for arthritis, joint pains; one of the ten roots in Dashamoola.
Poultices applied to skin ulcers, eczema, and inflammatory skin diseases.
Powdered whole plant taken to strengthen the body in convalescence and respiratory illness.

pharmacological_activities.name: Antipyretic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Reduction of yeast-induced fever in animal models.
pharmacological_activities.evidence: Lakshmi et al., Int J Pharm Sci Res. 2016

pharmacological_activities.name: Anti-arthritic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Reduces inflammation and joint swelling; suppresses arthritis symptoms.

pharmacological_activities.name: Analgesic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Decreases responses to pain in validated pain models.

pharmacological_activities.name: Antioxidant
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Free radical scavenging (ABTS, DPPH assays).

pharmacological_activities.name: Hepatoprotective
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Protects liver tissue from chemical injury.

pharmacological_activities.name: Antimicrobial
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Prevents growth of S. aureus & P. aeruginosa.
pharmacological_activities.evidence: Selvakumar & Naveen, BMC Complement Altern Med. 2019

pharmacological_activities.name: Immunostimulant
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Enhances immune markers in animal studies.
pharmacological_activities.evidence: Veerendra et al., J. Immunol Res. 2016

pharmacological_activities.name: Anti-inflammatory
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: NF-κB pathway inhibition.

pharmacological_activities.name: Cytotoxic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Selective activity against HeLa cancer cell lines.

modern_applications: Plant extracts in joint health and anti-arthritic nutraceuticals.
Ingredient in polyherbal skin creams for inflammatory dermatoses.

safety.acute_toxicity: No acute toxicity up to 2g/kg in rodents; considered safe in recommended Ayurveda doses.
precautions: Avoid unregulated high-dose use.
Pregnancy safety evidence lacking: traditional avoidance advised.

references: Lakshmi et al., Int J Pharm Sci Res. 2016
Veerendra et al., J. Immunol Res. 2016
Selvakumar & Naveen, BMC Complement Altern Med. 2019

description.overview: Aromatic perennial herb widely used as a food flavoring, digestive aid, and medicinal plant across the world.
description.habitat: Native to temperate Europe and Asia; naturalized and cultivated worldwide.

iucn_status.status: Varies by species; none of the commonly cultivated mints are endangered.
sources: Kew Plants of the World Online

traditional_uses.context: Mint leaf tea or infusions used to soothe indigestion, gas and colic.
Inhaled vapor or tea for relief of cough, sore throat, and mild asthma.
Mentholated balm or oil massaged on forehead for tension headaches.
Leaves used in chutneys, sauces, beverages, and as garnish in cuisines globally.

pharmacological_activities.name: Spasmolytic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Relaxes smooth muscle, especially in digestive tract.

pharmacological_activities.name: Antioxidant
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Free radical scavenging, protection against oxidative stress.

pharmacological_activities.name: Antimicrobial
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Active against oral, enteric, and skin bacteria.

pharmacological_activities.name: Anti-inflammatory
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Inhibits COX-1/COX-2; prostaglandin synthesis reduced.

pharmacological_activities.name: Analgesic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Menthol activates cold-sensitive TRPM8 receptors for topical pain relief.

pharmacological_activities.name: Neuroprotective
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Rosmarinic acid protects neurons from oxidative damage.

pharmacological_activities.name: Carminative
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Relieves bloating and flatulence (clinical trials).

pharmacological_activities.name: Bronchodilatory
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Relaxes bronchial muscle, enhances airflow.

pharmacological_activities.name: Antiemetic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Reduces nausea and vomiting in chemotherapy models.

pharmacological_activities.name: Gastroprotective
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Decreases ulcer formation in gastric injury models.

modern_applications: Mint oil in toothpaste, mouthwash, gels, creams, and topical analgesics.
Leaf extract in digestive supplements and functional beverages.
Food industry as a flavor and antimicrobial agent.

safety.acute_toxicity: Topical preparations containing up to 10% menthol are generally safe; oral mint leaves are GRAS. Pure essential oil can be toxic in high oral doses.
safety.chronic_toxicity: No significant adverse effects with culinary use. Chronic use of high-dose oil may cause GI complaints or allergy.
precautions: Essential oil should not be consumed in large quantities.
Topical menthol can cause dermatitis in hypersensitive individuals.
Pulegone-containing wild mints can be hepatotoxic (avoid pennyroyal oil).
sources: WHO Monographs on Selected Medicinal Plants

description.overview: A rare Acanthaceae shrub endemic to the Western Ghats, integrated into Kerala and Tamil folk medicine for rheumatism and blood purification.
description.habitat: Mountain peaks, forested slopes, and valleys of Kerala and Tamil Nadu (Western Ghats).

iucn_status.status: Not formally assessed (likely Vulnerable regionally); threatened by habitat loss, overharvesting.

traditional_uses.context: Leaf and stem decoction taken orally for relief from joint pain, arthritis and rheumatism.
Herbal tea brewed as a traditional remedy to lower high fever.
Taken to stimulate circulation and 'cleanse' the blood in Kerala folk medicine.
Infused leaf oil massaged onto inflamed or aching joints.

pharmacological_activities.name: Anti-inflammatory
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Inhibits TNF-α and pro-inflammatory cytokines.

pharmacological_activities.name: Analgesic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Reduces pain in rodent hot-plate and tail-flick tests.

pharmacological_activities.name: Antioxidant
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Scavenges free radicals; phenolic/terpenoid basis.

pharmacological_activities.name: Hepatoprotective
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Attenuates CCl₄-induced liver damage.

pharmacological_activities.name: Antimicrobial
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Inhibits growth of Pseudomonas aeruginosa and other pathogens.

pharmacological_activities.name: Cytotoxic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Induces cell death in A549 carcinoma cell line.

pharmacological_activities.name: Immunostimulant
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Increases immunoglobulin G (IgG) titers in animal models.

modern_applications: Extracts investigated for anti-arthritic and pain-relief drug candidates.
Potential inclusion in topical formulas for joint pain and inflammation.

safety.acute_toxicity: No acute toxicity up to 2 g/kg; safe in traditional dose ranges.
safety.chronic_toxicity: No comprehensive long-term safety tested in humans.
precautions: Overuse of concentrated extracts not studied.
Not advised in pregnancy or without qualified supervision for long-term medicinal use.

description.overview: A fast-growing, drought-tolerant tree native to India, renowned for its nutritional and therapeutic properties especially for malnutrition and inflammatory disorders.
description.habitat: Native to sub-Himalayan India; cultivated across Asia, Africa, the Caribbean, Central and South America.

iucn_status.status: Not assessed on IUCN Red List; widely cultivated, not threatened.
sources: FAO Crop wild relatives report, IUCN (2024)

traditional_uses.context: Leaf powder or fresh leaves used as protein, vitamin-rich supplement for children, pregnant and lactating mothers.
Powder taken as rejuvenative in Ayurveda and African traditional medicine.
Externally applied leaf pastes for wound healing and inflammation.
Leaf or seed extracts used to treat stomach ulcers and gastric complaints.

pharmacological_activities.name: Anti-inflammatory
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Suppresses NF-κB pathway; reduces inflammatory biomarkers.

pharmacological_activities.name: Hypoglycemic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Reduces blood glucose and improves insulin sensitivity.

pharmacological_activities.name: Antioxidant
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Neutralizes free radicals due to polyphenols and vitamin C.

pharmacological_activities.name: Hepatoprotective
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Protects liver from paracetamol-induced and CCl₄-induced damage.

pharmacological_activities.name: Antimicrobial
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Active against diverse bacteria (e.g. S. aureus, E. coli) and fungi.

pharmacological_activities.name: Cytotoxic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Inhibits growth of prostate (PC-3) and other cancer cell lines.

pharmacological_activities.name: Anti-hypertensive
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Lowers blood pressure in hypertensive animal models.

pharmacological_activities.name: Wound healing
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Accelerates healing in excised wound animal models.

pharmacological_activities.name: Anti-ulcer
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Increases gastric mucus; improves ulcer healing.

pharmacological_activities.name: Immunomodulatory
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Increases IL-2 and TNF-α, improves immune status.

modern_applications: Moringa leaf powders and capsules in global nutrition and wellness markets.
Extracts in functional foods, beverages, smoothies and energy bars.
Leaf/seed extracts in cosmetics and wound-care.

safety.acute_toxicity: No toxicity up to 2 g/kg in animal studies. Traditionally consumed as food.
safety.chronic_toxicity: Very high consumption may affect thyroid and reproductive function.
precautions: Use under medical advice in pregnancy.
Large amounts may interfere with hypothyroid medication.
Root and root extracts are potentially toxic and not traditionally recommended.
sources: WHO Monograph on Selected Medicinal Plants

description.overview: A fast-growing small evergreen tree with sweet, red berries and soft leaves, traditionally valued for antipyretic and digestive uses.
description.habitat: Native to Central and South America; now pantropical, thriving in disturbed soils and urban settings across Asia and Africa.

sources: Plants of the World Online, Royal Botanic Gardens Kew

traditional_uses.context: Fruit or leaf decoction given for reducing fever in folk medicine of Southeast Asia and Central America.
Leaf tea and fruit syrup for gastrointestinal infections and dysentery.
Poultices of bark or leaves applied topically for minor wounds and inflammation.
Berry preserves recommended for stomach upset and as a nutritive tonic.

pharmacological_activities.name: Antipyretic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Reduces elevated body temperature in animal models.

pharmacological_activities.name: Antioxidant
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: DPPH, FRAP, and ABTS scavenging through high flavonoid and vitamin C content.

pharmacological_activities.name: Anti-inflammatory
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Suppresses COX-2 and inflammatory mediators.

pharmacological_activities.name: Analgesic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Reduces writhing and pain responses in mice.

pharmacological_activities.name: Antimicrobial
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Inhibits S. aureus and other pathogens.

pharmacological_activities.name: Hepatoprotective
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Reduces liver damage in CCl4 models.

pharmacological_activities.name: Anti-diabetic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: α-glucosidase inhibition leading to reduced blood sugar.

pharmacological_activities.name: Diuretic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Increases urine output in animal models.

pharmacological_activities.name: Wound healing
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Enhances excision-wound repair and re-epithelialization.

pharmacological_activities.name: Anti-ulcerogenic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Increases gastric mucus secretion and reduces ulceration.

modern_applications: Fruit extracts in antioxidant and antipyretic herbal formulations.
Development of functional foods and natural health products.

safety.acute_toxicity: No toxicity up to 1 g/kg in rodents (oral); high safety in dietary quantities.
safety.chronic_toxicity: No documented issues in traditional/food use.
precautions: Large extract doses can cause mild gastrointestinal effects.
Safe for children only in diluted preparations.
sources: WHO Southeast Asia Medicinal Plant Database

description.overview: A perennial aromatic shrub or small tree highly valued for its pungent, curry-scented leaves, used in South Asian cuisine and Ayurveda.
description.habitat: Native to India and Sri Lanka; cultivated in gardens and farms throughout tropical Asia.

iucn_status.status: Not Evaluated (NE); widely cultivated and common.
sources: India Biodiversity Portal, Kew Plants of the World Online

traditional_uses.context: Leaf decoctions and powders used to lower blood glucose in Ayurveda and folk medicine.
Leaves made into poultices for cuts, sores, and minor burns.
Leaves used to flavor food and for mild stomachic effect.
Roots used in traditional preparations for body aches.

pharmacological_activities.name: Antioxidant
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: FRAP and DPPH radical scavenging by leaf polyphenols.

pharmacological_activities.name: Anti-inflammatory
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Inhibits NF-κB and oxidative pathways.

pharmacological_activities.name: Hypolipidemic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Reduces serum lipids in high-fat diet rodents.

pharmacological_activities.name: Antimicrobial
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Activity against a range of bacterial and fungal pathogens.

pharmacological_activities.name: Hepatoprotective
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Mitigates paracetamol-induced liver damage.

pharmacological_activities.name: Neuroprotective
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Protects neurons from oxidative stress.

pharmacological_activities.name: Anti-diabetic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: α-amylase and α-glucosidase inhibition, reduced glucose absorption.

pharmacological_activities.name: Cytotoxic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Alkaloids show anticancer activity in MCF-7 cells.

pharmacological_activities.name: Analgesic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Reduces pain in hot-plate/tail-flick models.

pharmacological_activities.name: Larvicidal
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Toxic effects on mosquito larvae (Aedes aegypti).

modern_applications: Curry leaf extracts used in diabetes management supplements.
Hair and skin-care products using leaf/seed extracts.
Investigated for natural color and food preservation.

safety.acute_toxicity: No toxicity reported up to 2 g/kg in animal models.
safety.chronic_toxicity: Frequent culinary use regarded as safe.
precautions: May increase hypoglycemia risk when combined with drugs.
Consult professional if pregnant or lactating in medicinal doses.
sources: WHO Monograph on Selected Medicinal Plants

description.overview: A popular ornamental flowering shrub containing toxic cardiac glycosides; all parts highly poisonous if ingested.
description.habitat: Native to Mediterranean region and Southwest Asia; widely naturalized and cultivated.

iucn_status.status: Not Evaluated (NE); frequently cultivated and naturalized.

traditional_uses.context: Leaf poultices or ointments for arthritis, neuralgia, and swelling (external use only).
Diluted water extract as traditional headwash (strictly external).
Widely planted in temple gardens; used as an offering.

pharmacological_activities.name: Cardiotonic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Cardiac glycosides act on Na+/K+ ATPase to increase heart contractility (dangerous in overdose).

pharmacological_activities.name: Anticancer
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Oleandrin induces apoptosis in cancer cell lines.

pharmacological_activities.name: Anti-inflammatory
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: COX-2 and iNOS inhibition;

pharmacological_activities.name: Antimicrobial
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Efficacy against several bacteria (in vitro).

pharmacological_activities.name: Analgesic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Reduces pain in animal models.

pharmacological_activities.name: Molluscicidal
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Toxicity to pest snails (biopesticide research).

pharmacological_activities.name: Antioxidant
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Flavonoid- and glycoside-based scavenging.

pharmacological_activities.name: Insecticidal
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Plant extract acts as insect control agent.

pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Bark decoctions lower blood sugar in animal studies.

pharmacological_activities.name: Anti-inflammatory
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Leaf and bark inhibit cytokines and swelling.

modern_applications: Bark extracts in traditional antidiabetic supplements.
Leaf and bark used in wound-healing and skin-care formulations.

safety.acute_toxicity: No toxicity seen in animal studies up to 2 g/kg.
precautions: High dose may cause mild GI upset.
Pregnancy use only under supervision.

description.overview: An evergreen ornamental shrub with large red flowers, long valued in hair care and fever remedies.
description.habitat: Native to East Asia, widely cultivated as garden ornamental.

traditional_uses.context: Flower extracts in oils and shampoos to promote hair growth.
Flower teas for fever reduction and as a cooling drink.
Crushed leaves used for minor wounds and skin irritation.

pharmacological_activities.name: Antioxidant
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Anthocyanins scavenge free radicals.

pharmacological_activities.name: Wound healing
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Leaf and flower extracts enhance collagen and tissue repair.

pharmacological_activities.name: Anti-inflammatory
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Polyphenols reduce inflammatory response in animal models.

modern_applications: Extracts in cosmetic hair and skin-care products.
Hibiscus tea for antioxidant supplementation.

safety.acute_toxicity: Generally safe at normal doses.
precautions: High intake may lower blood pressure—caution in hypotension.
Rare allergic skin reactions possible.

botanical_name: Jasminum spp. (e.g. Jasminum sambac, Jasminum grandiflorum)

description.overview: A group of climbing/floriferous shrubs with aromatic white blossoms used in perfume, tea, traditional skin and mood remedies.
description.habitat: Native to tropical and subtropical Old World regions; cultivated in gardens, hedges, and for garland flowers.

iucn_status.status: Varies by species; common types are not threatened.

traditional_uses.context: Flowers in garlands, oils, and baths for mood and health.
Fresh or dried flowers infused for relaxing, antianxiety effects.
Leaf and flower poultices applied to skin cuts and boils.

pharmacological_activities.name: Sedative/Anxiolytic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Aromatics act on GABA receptors (in vitro, animal studies).

pharmacological_activities.name: Antioxidant
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Flavonoids neutralize free radicals.

pharmacological_activities.name: Wound healing
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Enhanced tissue regeneration when used topically.

modern_applications: Essential oils in perfumery and relaxation blends.
Jasmine green tea and calming herbal infusions.
Cosmetic and skin repair ingredient.

safety.acute_toxicity: Safe for aroma and culinary use.
precautions: Rare allergies in sensitive individuals.
Essential oil can irritate skin if undiluted.

description.overview: A tropical fruit tree producing sweet drupes (mangoes), with medicinal uses for bark, leaves and seeds.
description.habitat: Native to South Asia; cultivated globally in the tropics.

traditional_uses.context: Fruit eaten fresh, dried, or processed; unripe for pickles.
Bark decoction used for diarrhea and oral bleeding.
Leaf infusions taken for diabetes and cough.

pharmacological_activities.name: Antioxidant
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Mangiferin and other polyphenols neutralize ROS.

pharmacological_activities.name: Antidiabetic
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Leaf extracts lower blood glucose in animal models.

pharmacological_activities.name: Anti-inflammatory
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Bark and seed inhibit cytokine production.

modern_applications: Fruit pulp and juice in functional foods.
Leaf, bark and seed extracts as nutraceuticals for antioxidant support.

safety.acute_toxicity: Edible fruit and parts are safe at typical doses.
precautions: Unripe fruit may irritate stomach.
Latex or sap can cause dermatitis.

description.overview: A tropical fruit tree bearing sweet, brown fruits, also valued for chicle latex and some folk uses of bark.
description.habitat: Native to Central America and Mexico; cultivated widely in the tropics.

traditional_uses.context: Fruit enjoyed fresh as nutritious dessert.
Latex tapped ('chicle') for use in chewing gum.
Bark tea used in folk medicine for GI upsets.

pharmacological_activities.name: Antioxidant
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Polyphenols scavenge free radicals.

pharmacological_activities.name: Antimicrobial
pharmacological_activities.mechanism: Bark and seed inhibit growth of oral/pathogenic bacteria.

modern_applications: Fruit pulps in frozen desserts and superfood mixes.
Latex used for natural chewing gum base.

safety.acute_toxicity: No reported toxicity in traditional or modern use.
precautions: Fruit is high in sugar; diabetic patients should moderate use.
Unprocessed latex not suitable for direct medicinal use.
